content.text: Welcome to your first Dutch conversation! You're at a *borrel* (a casual networking event) in Eindhoven. A friendly local approaches you.

data.tip: It's a short, sharp sound. Be careful not to say 'ick' as in 'icky'.

content.title: Introduce Yourself
content.setting: You're at a casual networking event in Eindhoven. Someone walks up to you and starts a conversation.

conversation_flow.title: State your name.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Hoi! Ik ben Thomas. Hoe heet jij?

extract_info.user_origin_country: The country the user says they are from.

content.text: Cultural Tip: Dutch people are often very direct. Asking about your job ('Wat voor werk doe je?') right away is common and friendly!

data.tip: The 'oo' sound is long, like the 'o' in the English word 'vote'.

content.title: Talk About Your Life
content.setting: The conversation with Thomas continues. He's curious to know more about you.

conversation_flow.title: State your profession.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ah, {user_origin_country}! Interessant. En wat voor werk doe je?

conversation_flow.title: Say where you live now.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Oké, een {user_job}. Leuk! En woon je hier in Eindhoven?

extract_info.user_city: The city where the user currently lives.

content.text: Time to ask questions back! It's polite to show you're interested in them, too. 'En jij?' is the easiest way to return a question.

data.tip: This sounds exactly like the English word 'yay'.

content.title: Reciprocate
content.setting: You've shared some details. Now, turn the conversation back to Thomas.

conversation_flow.title: Ask 'And you?' to find out what he does.
Say 'Nice to meet you'.
conversation_flow.chatbot_message: Ik ben softwareontwikkelaar bij ASML. Het was leuk om met je te praten, {user_name}!
